The second premise is the negation of the consequent: "It's not the case that the truck must have been blue." This can be represented as "Not Q."

The conclusion is the negation of the antecedent: "The car was not red." This can be represented as "Not P."

This argument structure is a classic example of modus tollens, which is a valid argument form. In modus tollens, if we have "If P, then Q" and "Not Q," we can infer "Not P."
